sentence: The Q4 earnings season has reached the tail end for all sectors save retail which yet to come up with more than half of its total Q4 reports.
Total earnings for the sector that has reported so far are up 1.9%, better than the third-quarter earnings decline of 1.1% but below the four-quarter average of 3.7%.
Revenue growth of 8.8% is, no doubt, better than both the third-quarter and the four-quarter averages.

Earnings surprises are impressive at 70% with more retailers beating estimates relative to Q3 and the four-quarter average while revenue beat of 55% is below Q3 but higher than the four-quarter average.

Given the encouraging results so far, retail stocks are driving higher, gaining at an average of 4.36% (average price difference between a day before and after the earnings announcement of a stock), as per the Zacks Earnings Trends .
In fact, the sector is the best performer in the S&P 500, crushing the broader index from the year-to-date look as well as the trailing 52-weeks.
The robust performance of the sector is primarily driven by higher consumer spending, which rose at 4.3% in the fourth quarter, reflecting the fastest pace since 2006.

This is especially true as a stronger economy, better job and wage prospects, and lower oil price are leading to fatter wallets and greater spending power (read: 2 Sector ETFs to Benefit from the Crude Oil Slump ).
Further, the U.S. consumer confidence hit the peak since August 2007, as measured by the Conference Board.
The Consumer Confidence Index jumped to 102.9 in January from a revised 93.1 in December.
On the other hand, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan index of consumer sentiment increased to the highest level in 11 years at 98.1 in January, up from 93.6 in December.
Moreover, retail sales nudged up 0.1% in January indicating a soft start to 2015, but fared better than the 0.3% drop recorded in December.
The overall retail sector has been trending up buoyed by the Q4 optimism and is performing better than the other sectors.

This trend is likely to continue with Wal-Mart ( WMT ) reporting earnings today and other major retailers such as Home Depot ( HD ), Lowe's ( LOW ), Macy's ( M ), Target ( TGT ), and J. C. Penney ( JCP ) releasing earnings next week.
Given this, investors seeking a broad sector play could look at some of the top-ranked ETFs having a Zacks ETF Rank of 1 (Strong Buy) or 2 (Buy).
These funds are expected to outperform in the months to come and could be excellent picks to tap the space (read: all the Top Ranked ETFs ).
This duo has enjoyed a strong momentum and is leading the broad market fund ( SPY ) by wide margins from one-month look.
This is because it has potentially superior weighting methodologies, which could allow it to continue leading the retail space in the coming months as well.
This fund tracks the Market Vectors US Listed Retail 25 Index and holds about 26 stocks in its basket.
It is a large cap centric fund and is heavily concentrated on the top 10 holdings with 63.7% of assets - the largest allocations going to Wal-Mart, Amazon.com ( AMZN ) and HD.

Sector wise, specialty retail occupies the top position with less than one-third share, followed by double-digit allocation to hypermarkets, drug stores, departmental stores, and health care services.
The fund has amassed $259.1 million in its asset base while average daily volume is moderate at 79,000 shares.
Expense ratio came in at 0.35%.
The product has a Zacks ETF Rank of 1 with a Medium risk outlook and has surged 6.8% over the past one month.
This product tracks the S&P Retail Select Industry Index, holding 103 securities in its basket.
It is widely spread across each component as none of these holds more than 1.36% of total assets.
Small cap stocks dominate more than half of the portfolio while the rest have been split between the other two market cap levels (read: Should You Keep Holding the Retail ETFs?
In terms of sector holdings, apparel retail takes the top spot at one-fourth share while specialty stores, automotive retail and Internet retail also have double-digit allocations.
XRT is the most popular and actively traded ETF in the retail space with AUM of about $1.5 billion and average daily volume of more than 2.3 million shares.
It charges 35 bps in annual fees and has added nearly 5% over the past one month.
The fund has a Zacks ETF Rank of 2 with a Medium risk outlook.
With surging consumer spending, better job markets and the Q4 earnings fervor, these top ranked ETFs should continue their upward journey.
